description: Learned borrowing from Latin successus, from succēdō (“succeed”), from sub- (“next to”) + cēdō (“go, move”). Partly displaced native Old English spēd, whence Modern English speed.

entries.meaning: The achievement of one's aim or goal. [from 16th c.]
examples: His third attempt to pass the entrance exam was a success.
Don't let success go to your head.

entries.meaning: One who, or that which, achieves assumed goals.
examples: The new range of toys has been a resounding success.

entries.meaning: The fact of getting or achieving wealth, respect, or fame.
examples: She is country music's most recent success.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Something which happens as a consequence; the outcome or result. [16th–18th c.]
